questions.question_text: Which of the following lists the correct common names for ethanal, methanal, and ethanol, respectively?
questions.explanation: The common name of ethanal is acetaldehyde, the common name of methanal is formaldehyde, and the common name of ethanol is ethyl alcohol. Isopropyl alcohol is the common name of 2-propanol. Propionaldehyde is the common name of propanal.
questions.short_reason: ACE-FORM-ETHYL: Acetaldehyde (ethanal), Formaldehyde (methanal), Ethyl alcohol (ethanol) - the 'common' names come from historical roots, not IUPAC counting!

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Ethyl alcohol is ethanol, not ethanal. Propionaldehyde is propanal (3 carbons), not methanal (1 carbon).
wrong_answer_explanations.C: The order is scrambled - ethyl alcohol is ethanol, not ethanal; formaldehyde matches methanal correctly, but acetaldehyde is ethanal, not ethanol.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Isopropyl alcohol is 2-propanol (3 carbons with OH on middle carbon), not ethanal (2-carbon aldehyde).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why 'Acetaldehyde, formaldehyde, ethyl alcohol' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following are considered terminal functional groups?
I. Aldehydes
II. Ketones
III. Carboxylic acids
questions.explanation: Aldehydes and carboxylic acids are characterized by their positions at the ends of carbon backbones and are thus considered terminal groups. As a result, the carbons to which they are attached are usually designated carbon 1. Ketones are internal by definition because there must be a carbon on either side of the carbonyl.
questions.short_reason: Terminal = END of the line! Aldehydes and carboxylic acids MUST be at carbon 1 (the end). Ketones need carbons on BOTH sides, so they're always internal.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Carboxylic acids are also terminal - they must be at the end of the carbon chain just like aldehydes.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Aldehydes are terminal too! The -CHO group must be at the end of the chain.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Ketones require a carbon on EACH side of the C=O, making them internal by definition - they cannot be terminal.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why 'I and III only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: If all prefixes were dropped, what would be the name of the parent root of this molecule?
questions.explanation: The highest-priority functional group in this molecule is the carboxyl group, so this will be a component of the backbone and provides the suffix of the molecule. This molecule is 2-methyl-3-oxopropanoic acid.
questions.short_reason: Priority rules: Carboxylic acid (-COOH) beats ketone (C=O) beats alcohol (-OH). The highest priority group determines the suffix!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Propanoate is an ester or salt form - this molecule has a free carboxylic acid, not a propanoate.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Propanol would have -OH as the main functional group, but here -COOH takes priority over any alcohol.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Anhydride requires TWO acyl groups joined by oxygen - this is a single carboxylic acid molecule.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why 'Propanoic acid' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the highest-priority functional group in this molecule?
questions.explanation: This molecule features an anhydride. The only other groups are hydrocarbon chains, which will provide part of the name of the parent root. Keep in mind that when a carbonyl group is present with a leaving group, the larger functional group (carboxylic acid, anhydride, ester, amide) takes priority over the carbonyl group alone. This molecule is propanoic anhydride.
questions.short_reason: Anhydrides are 'double acid' structures (two C=O groups sharing an oxygen). When a leaving group is attached to a carbonyl, name the WHOLE functional group, not just the C=O!

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Carbonyl is too general - it's part of the anhydride but doesn't capture the full functional group identity.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Ketones have alkyl groups on both sides of C=O with no leaving group - anhydrides have the -O-C(=O)- pattern.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Alkyl chains are always lowest priority - any oxygen-containing functional group takes precedence.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why 'Anhydride' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name for the following structure ends in what suffix?
questions.explanation: Among the functional groups presented, carboxylic acids have the highest priority, and their compounds end with an –oic acid suffix. (A) denotes an alcohol, (B) a ketone, and (D) an alkyne, all of which have lower priorities than carboxylic acids. The MCAT does not test nomenclature of halides or ethers, but note that these must have lower priority than a carboxylic acid because they are less oxidized groups.
questions.short_reason: Carboxylic acids are KING of functional group priority! Remember: -oic acid suffix means COOH is present and takes charge.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: -ol denotes alcohols, which have lower priority than carboxylic acids in naming.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: -one denotes ketones, which rank below carboxylic acids in the priority hierarchy.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: -yne denotes alkynes (triple bonds), which are very low priority - just modifiers, not main suffixes when acids are present.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why '–oic acid' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the two possibilities below correctly numbers the carbon backbone of this molecule?

options.C: Numbering schemes 1 and 2 are equivalent and correct.
options.D: Numbering schemes 1 and 2 are equivalent and incorrect.

questions.explanation: This molecule is 3-ethyl-4-methylhexane, not 2,3-diethylpentane. When naming alkanes, one must locate the longest carbon chain (6 carbons rather than 5 carbons), and the numbering system should give the alkyl groups the lowest possible numbers.
questions.short_reason: LONGEST chain first, then LOWEST numbers! Find the longest continuous carbon chain, then number to give substituents the smallest possible position numbers.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: This creates a 5-carbon chain when a 6-carbon chain exists - always find the LONGEST chain first!
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Both schemes can't be correct - only one numbering gives the lowest substituent numbers.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Both schemes can't be incorrect - one of them must correctly identify the longest chain with lowest numbers.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why 'Numbering scheme 1' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the proper structure for 2,3-dihydroxybutanedioic acid (tartaric acid)?
questions.explanation: We know from the IUPAC name that we have a butanedioic acid backbone—in other words, a four-carbon backbone with carboxylic acids at either end. Adding the hydroxyl groups at carbons 2 and 3 then yields the correct structure.
questions.short_reason: Decode the name piece by piece: butane = 4 carbons, dioic acid = COOH on BOTH ends, 2,3-dihydroxy = OH on carbons 2 and 3.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Check if this structure has 4 carbons with carboxylic acids at positions 1 and 4, plus hydroxyls at 2 and 3.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Verify the carbon count and functional group positions match the IUPAC name requirements.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Ensure the dicarboxylic acid backbone (dioic) and dihydroxy substituents are correctly placed.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why 'HOOC—CH(OH)—CH(OH)—COOH (correct structure)' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The common names for the aldehydes and carboxylic acids that contain only one carbon start with which prefix?
questions.explanation: Form– is a prefix shared by the common names of methanoic acid (formic acid) and methanal (formaldehyde).
questions.short_reason: FORM- = 1 carbon (like FORMic acid from FORMica ants). ACET- = 2 carbons (like vinegar/ACETic acid). METH- is IUPAC, not common!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Para- describes substitution patterns on benzene rings, not carbon chain length.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Meth- is the IUPAC prefix for one carbon, but the question asks for COMMON name prefixes.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Acet- is the common prefix for TWO-carbon compounds (acetaldehyde, acetic acid), not one-carbon.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why 'Form–' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the IUPAC name for the following structure?
questions.explanation: The first task in naming a compound is identifying the longest carbon chain. In this case, the longest chain has seven carbons, so the parent alkane ends in –heptane. (B) and (D) can therefore be eliminated. Then, we must make sure that the carbons are numbered so that the substituents’ position numbers are as small as possible. This compound has two methyl groups; minimizing their position numbers requires us to number the chain from right to left. These methyl groups are attached to carbons 2 and 5, so the correct IUPAC name is 2,5-dimethylheptane. (C) is incorrect because the position numbers of the substituents are not minimized.
questions.short_reason: Step 1: Find LONGEST chain (7 carbons = heptane). Step 2: Number to give LOWEST substituent positions (2,5 < 3,6). Alphabetize substituents in name!

wrong_answer_explanations.B: This creates a 6-carbon chain with ethyl substituent when a 7-carbon chain exists - not the longest chain!
wrong_answer_explanations.C: While correctly identifying heptane, numbering 3,6 gives higher position numbers than 2,5.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Same error as B - ethyl as substituent means you didn't find the longest possible chain.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why '2,5-dimethylheptane' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the IUPAC name for the following structure?
questions.explanation: We begin by finding the longest carbon chain; because there are no non-alkyl groups, we don’t need to worry about any other groups’ priorities. We then number our carbons such that the lowest possible combination of numbers is given to the various substituents. Then substituents are organized alphabetically, not numerically—eliminating (C).
questions.short_reason: Alphabetize substituents (Ethyl before Methyl), then number for lowest positions. Ignore 'iso' and 'di/tri' prefixes when alphabetizing!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Isopropyl groups should be broken into their component methyl and ethyl substituents for correct naming.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Numbers are reversed - always number to give lowest position numbers for substituents.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Substituents must be listed alphabetically (ethyl before trimethyl), not numerically.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why '3-ethyl-2,2,5-trimethylhexane' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name for the following structure starts with what prefix?
questions.explanation: We know right away that (C) and (D) will be incorrect because a hydroxyl group is of higher priority than a methyl group. We also know that we will number the carbon chain so that the hydroxyl group receives the lowest possible position. Therefore, this molecule is 2-methyl-2-butanol, which starts with the prefix 2-methyl.
questions.short_reason: High priority groups get numbered FIRST! -OH (alcohol) outranks -CH3 (methyl), so the alcohol position determines the numbering direction.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 3-methyl would mean numbering from the wrong end - alcohol should get the lower number.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Hydroxy isn't used as a prefix when -OH is the highest priority group - it becomes the suffix (-ol).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Same issue - hydroxy as prefix means you're not treating alcohol as the main functional group.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why '2-methyl-' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
NADH is a coenzyme that releases high-energy electrons into the electron transport chain. It is known as nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide or diphosphopyridine nucleotide. What functional groups exist in this molecule?
I. Phosphate
II. Amide
III. Anhydride
questions.explanation: The suffix –amide in nicotinamide indicates that this compound contains an amide functional group. The prefix diphospho– indicates that there are two phosphate groups as well. Even if we did not know the prefix phospho– from this chapter, we should recognize that nucleotides, mentioned in the name of the compound, contain a sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base. The structure of NAD+, the oxidized form of NADH, is shown below.
questions.short_reason: Read the name like a code: NicotinAMIDE = amide group, DiPHOSPHO = phosphate groups. Nucleotide = sugar + phosphate + base. No anhydride linkage here!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: NADH has more than just phosphate - the nicotinamide part clearly indicates an amide functional group.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: The amide is correct, but diphospho- tells us there are phosphate groups too!
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Anhydrides require two acyl groups sharing an oxygen - the phosphate groups in NADH are linked differently (as phosphodiesters).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why 'I and II only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Pyruvic acid, one of the end products of glycolysis, is commonly called acetylformic acid. Based on its common name, the structure of pyruvic acid must be:
questions.explanation: We can use the name acetylformic acid to figure out what our functional groups are. The prefix acet– refers to a two-carbon unit with one carbon in a carbonyl group—think of acetic acid, acetic anhydride, or acetaldehyde. The carbonyl carbon is the point of attachment to another functional group. Formic acid is a single-carbon carboxylic acid. Therefore, acetylformic acid is an acetyl group directly attached to formic acid, as shown in (A). (B) shows acetic acid, or vinegar; (C) shows glucose; and (D) shows formic acid.
questions.short_reason: ACETYL = 2C with carbonyl (CH3-C=O-), FORMIC = 1C carboxylic acid. Combine them: acetyl-formic acid = CH3-CO-COOH = pyruvic acid!

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Acetic acid (CH3COOH) is just the acetyl group with -OH, missing the formic acid portion.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Glucose is a 6-carbon sugar with multiple -OH groups - completely different structure.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Formic acid (HCOOH) alone is missing the acetyl (2-carbon) portion of the name.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why 'CH₃—CO—COOH (2-oxopropanoic acid)' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following are common names for carboxylic acid derivatives?
I. Acetic anhydride
II. Formic acid
III. Methyl formate
questions.explanation: Acetic anhydride is the common name for ethanoic anhydride. Methyl formate is the common name for methyl methanoate; we can infer this from the common root form– and the ester suffix –oate (which is sometimes shortened to –ate for pronunciation purposes). Formic acid is the common name for methanoic acid, but this is a carboxylic acid—not a derivative.
questions.short_reason: Derivatives are MODIFIED carboxylic acids! Anhydrides and esters (methyl formate) come FROM acids. The parent acid itself (formic acid) is NOT a derivative.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Formic acid is the PARENT carboxylic acid, not a derivative of one.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Again, formic acid is the parent compound - methyl formate (ester) IS a derivative.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Formic acid cannot be both a carboxylic acid AND a carboxylic acid derivative - it's the original, not the modified form.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why 'I and III only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Consider the name 2,3-diethylpentane. Based on the structure implied by this name, the correct IUPAC name for this molecule is:
questions.explanation: Draw out the molecule, and you will see that the longest carbon chain with the substituents at the lowest possible carbon numbers is actually different from the one chosen in the original name. The correct IUPAC name for this molecule is 3-ethyl-4-methylhexane.
questions.short_reason: Draw it out! 2,3-diethylpentane drawn correctly reveals a 6-carbon main chain, not 5. Rename with longest chain and lowest substituent numbers.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: The name suggests a 5-carbon chain, but drawing reveals a longer 6-carbon backbone exists.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 1,2-diethylbutane would be an incorrect representation of the actual structure.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Substituents must be listed alphabetically - ethyl comes before methyl.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Nomenclature: Explain why '3-ethyl-4-methylhexane.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following does NOT show optical activity?

options.C: A solution containing 1 M (R)-2-butanol and 2 M (S)-2-butanol
options.D: A solution containing 2 M (R)-2-butanol and 2 M (S)-2-butanol

questions.explanation: This is a racemic mixture of 2-butanol because it consists of equimolar amounts of (R)-2-butanol and (S)-2-butanol. The (R)-2-butanol molecule rotates the plane of polarized light in one direction, and the (S)-2-butanol rotates it by the same angle but in the opposite direction; as a result, no net rotation of polarized light is observed.
questions.short_reason: Racemic = 50:50 mix = ZERO optical activity! Equal amounts of R and S rotate light equally but OPPOSITE directions, canceling out.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: (R)-2-butanol is a single enantiomer - it WILL rotate plane-polarized light.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: (S)-2-butanol is also a single enantiomer - it rotates light in the opposite direction from R.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Unequal mixture (1M vs 2M) means there's excess S-enantiomer - net rotation toward S direction occurs.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'A solution containing 2 M (R)-2-butanol and 2 M (S)-2-butanol' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: How many stereoisomers exist for the following aldehyde?
questions.explanation: The maximum number of stereoisomers of a compound equals 2n, where n is the number of chiral carbons in the compound. In this molecule, C-1 (the aldehydic carbon) is not chiral, nor is C-5 (because it is attached to two hydrogen atoms). Therefore, with three chiral centers, there are 23 = 8 stereoisomers.
questions.short_reason: Count chiral carbons, use 2^n formula! Each chiral center = 4 different groups attached. Double bonds and CH2 groups = NOT chiral.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Only 2 stereoisomers would mean just 1 chiral center - count more carefully!
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 9 isn't a power of 2 - stereoisomer count is always 2^n for n chiral centers.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 16 = 2^4 would require 4 chiral centers - this molecule has only 3.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why '8' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following compounds is optically inactive?
questions.explanation: This answer choice is an example of a meso compound—a compound that contains chiral centers but has an internal plane of symmetry: Owing to this internal plane of symmetry, the molecule is achiral and, hence, optically inactive. (A) and (B) are enantiomers of each other and will certainly show optical activity on their own. (D), because it contains a chiral carbon and no internal plane of symmetry, is optically active as well.
questions.short_reason: MESO = chiral centers BUT internal mirror plane = optically INACTIVE! The molecule's own halves cancel each other's rotation.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: This structure has chiral centers without an internal plane of symmetry - it will be optically active.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Also lacks internal symmetry - a single enantiomer that will rotate light.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Has chiral carbon(s) without compensating symmetry - optically active.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'meso-tartaric acid (internal plane of symmetry)' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Cholesterol, shown below, contains how many chiral centers?
questions.explanation: To be considered a chiral center, a carbon must have four different substituents. There are eight stereocenters in this molecule, which are marked below with asterisks. The other carbons are not chiral for various reasons. Many are bonded to two hydrogens; others participate in double bonds, which count as two bonds to the same atom.
questions.short_reason: Chiral = 4 DIFFERENT substituents! Carbons in double bonds, attached to 2 H's, or at ring junctions with identical paths are NOT chiral.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 5 is too few - look more carefully at ring junction carbons.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 7 is close but misses one stereocenter.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 9 overcounts - some carbons don't have 4 different groups attached.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why '8' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which isomer of the following compound is the most stable?

options.A: Chair with both methyl groups axial
options.B: Chair with both methyl groups equatorial (trans)
options.C: Chair with one methyl axial, one equatorial

questions.explanation: This molecule is a chair conformation in which the two equatorial methyl groups are trans to each other. Because the axial methyl hydrogens do not compete for the same space as the hydrogens attached to the ring, this conformation ensures the least amount of steric strain. (A) would be less stable because the diaxial methyl group hydrogens are closer to the hydrogens on the ring, causing greater steric strain. (C) is incorrect because it is in the more unstable boat conformation.
questions.short_reason: EQUATORIAL = happy, AXIAL = sad! Large groups prefer equatorial positions to avoid 1,3-diaxial interactions. Chair > boat stability.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Diaxial methyl groups create steric strain from 1,3-diaxial interactions with ring hydrogens.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Boat conformations have flagpole interactions and torsional strain - less stable than chair.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: The conformations have very different steric strain - they are NOT equally stable.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'Chair with both methyl groups equatorial (trans)' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The following reaction results in:

options.A: retention of relative configuration and a change in the absolute configuration.
options.B: a change in the relative and absolute configurations.
options.C: retention of the relative and absolute configurations.
options.D: retention of the absolute configuration and a change in the relative configuration.

questions.explanation: The relative configuration is retained because the bonds of the stereocenter are not broken; thus, the positions of groups around the chiral carbon are maintained. The absolute configuration is also retained because both the reactant and product are (R).
questions.short_reason: If you don't BREAK bonds at the stereocenter, configuration is RETAINED! Reactions away from the chiral carbon preserve both relative and absolute configuration.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Absolute configuration is retained (still R), and since bonds weren't broken at stereocenter, relative is also kept.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Neither configuration changes when the stereocenter is uninvolved in the reaction.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Absolute configuration doesn't change - the stereocenter wasn't touched!

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'retention of the relative and absolute configurations.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The following molecules are considered to be:
questions.explanation: These compounds are nonsuperimposable mirror images. To make analysis a bit easier, we can rotate structure II 180° to look like structure III. Structures I and III more clearly have opposite stereochemistry at every chiral center, meaning that they are enantiomers. (B) is incorrect because diastereomers are stereoisomers that are not mirror images of each other. (C) is incorrect because meso compounds must contain a plane of symmetry, which neither of these molecules has. (D) is incorrect because structural isomers are compounds with the same molecular formula but different atomic connections. The connectivity in these two molecules is the same, which means that they are stereoisomers, not structural isomers.
questions.short_reason: Mirror images with OPPOSITE stereochemistry at ALL chiral centers = ENANTIOMERS. Different at SOME but not all = diastereomers.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Diastereomers differ at SOME chiral centers but not all - these differ at ALL centers.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Meso compounds have INTERNAL symmetry - these molecules don't have mirror planes within them.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Structural isomers have different connectivity - these have the same bonds, just different spatial arrangement.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'enantiomers.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: (+)-Glyceraldehyde and (–)-glyceraldehyde refer to the (R) and (S) forms of 2,3-dihydroxypropanal, respectively. These molecules are considered:
questions.explanation: (+)-Glyceraldehyde and (–)-glyceraldehyde, or (R)- and (S)-2,3-dihydroxypropanal, are enantiomers. Enantiomers are nonsuperimposable mirror images. Each has only one chiral center (C-2), which has opposite absolute configuration in these two molecules.
questions.short_reason: Same molecule, opposite rotations (+/-), opposite configurations (R/S) = ENANTIOMERS! Mirror images that can't be superimposed.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Diastereomers have some but not all opposite configurations - glyceraldehyde has only ONE chiral center.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Meso compounds are single molecules with internal symmetry - these are TWO different molecules.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Structural isomers have different atomic connections - these have identical connectivity.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'enantiomers.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Consider (E)-2-butene and (Z)-2-butene. This is a pair of what type(s) of isomers?
I. Cis–trans isomers
II. Diastereomers
III. Enantiomers
questions.explanation: (E)-2-butene can also be called trans-2-butene; (Z)-2-butene can also be called cis-2-butene. As such, they are cis–trans isomers. Remember that cis–trans isomers are a subtype of diastereomers in which the position of substituents differs about an immovable bond. Diastereomers are molecules that are non-mirror-image stereoisomers (molecules with the same atomic connectivity). These are not enantiomers because they are not mirror images of each other.
questions.short_reason: E/Z = cis/trans = GEOMETRIC isomers = a TYPE of diastereomer! Same formula, same connections, different spatial arrangement around a double bond.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Cis-trans isomers are actually a SUBSET of diastereomers - both I and II apply.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: While technically diastereomers, these specific ones are better known as cis-trans isomers.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: These are not enantiomers - they're not mirror images. E and Z are diastereomers.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'I and II only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: 3-methylpentane and hexane are related in that they are:
questions.explanation: Because they have the same molecular formula but different atomic connectivity, 3-methylpentane and hexane are constitutional isomers.
questions.short_reason: Same molecular formula + DIFFERENT atom connections = CONSTITUTIONAL (structural) isomers. The carbons are bonded in different arrangements!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Enantiomers have the SAME connections but different 3D arrangement - these have different connections.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Diastereomers also require same connectivity - these molecules are connected differently.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Conformational isomers can interconvert by rotation - you can't rotate a bond to turn hexane into 3-methylpentane.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'constitutional isomers.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: (R)-2-chloro-(S)-3-bromobutane and (S)-2-chloro-(S)-3-bromobutane are:
questions.explanation: These two molecules are stereoisomers of one another, but are not nonsuperimposable mirror images. Therefore, they are diastereomers. Note that these molecules differ by at least one, but not all, chiral carbons.
questions.short_reason: Different at ONE stereocenter, same at another = DIASTEREOMERS! For enantiomers, ALL stereocenters must be opposite.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Enantiomers require ALL chiral centers to have opposite configuration - only one differs here.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Meso compounds are single molecules with internal symmetry - these are two different molecules.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: They have opposite configuration at C-2, so they cannot be the same molecule.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'diastereomers.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A scientist takes a solution of an unknown pure dextrorotatory organic molecule and places it in a test tube with a diameter of 1 cm. He observes that a plane of polarized light is rotated 12° under these conditions. What is the specific rotation of this molecule?
questions.explanation: Remember that the equation for specific rotation is . In this example, αobs is +12° (remember that dextrorotatory, or clockwise, rotation is considered positive), Remember that path length is always measured in decimeters when calculating specific rotation. Therefore, the specific rotation can be calculated as:
questions.short_reason: Specific rotation formula: [alpha] = observed rotation / (path length in dm x concentration). Remember: dextrorotatory = positive (+)!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: -240 would indicate levorotatory, but dextrorotatory means positive rotation.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: -24 is wrong sign AND wrong magnitude - check your path length units!
wrong_answer_explanations.C: +24 has correct sign but incorrect calculation - path length must be in decimeters.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why '+240°' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor commonly used in gastroesophageal reflux disease. When omeprazole, a racemic mixture, went off-patent, pharmaceutical companies began to manufacture esomeprazole, the (S)-enantiomer of omeprazole, by itself. Given 1 M solutions of omeprazole and esomeprazole, which solution(s) would likely exhibit optical activity?
questions.explanation: Racemic mixtures like omeprazole contain equimolar amounts of two enantiomers and thus have no observed optical activity. Each of the two enantiomers causes rotation in opposite directions, so their effects cancel out. Esomeprazole only contains one of the two enantiomers and thus should cause rotation of plane-polarized light.
questions.short_reason: RACEMIC mixture = 50:50 R and S = NO net rotation. Single enantiomer (esomeprazole = S only) = optical activity!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Omeprazole is racemic (equal R and S) - rotations cancel, no net optical activity.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Omeprazole's R and S enantiomers cancel each other's rotations - only pure enantiomers show activity.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Esomeprazole is a single enantiomer - it definitely rotates plane-polarized light.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'Esomeprazole only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
(2R,3S)-2,3-dihydroxybutanedioic acid and (2S,3R)-2,3-dihydroxybutanedioic acid are:
I. meso compounds.
II. the same molecule.
III. enantiomers.
questions.explanation: Draw out these structures. The two names describe the same molecule, which also happens to be a meso compound because it contains a plane of symmetry. These compounds are not enantiomers because they are superimposable mirror images of one another, not nonsuperimposable mirror images. These compounds are better termed meso-2,3-dihydroxybutanedioic acid:
questions.short_reason: Draw it! 2R,3S and 2S,3R in this symmetric molecule are actually the SAME meso compound - the internal mirror plane makes them superimposable!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: While this IS a meso compound, the two names describe the same molecule, not different ones.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: These aren't enantiomers - drawing shows they're superimposable (the same meso compound).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: I and II are correct - it's a meso compound AND they're the same molecule.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'I and II only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: If the methyl groups of butane are 120° apart, as seen in a Newman projection, this molecule is in its:
questions.explanation: In butane, the position at which the two methyl groups are 120° apart is an eclipsed conformation. This has a moderate amount of energy, although not as high as a totally eclipsed conformation in which the two methyl groups are 0° apart.
questions.short_reason: Newman projection at 120 degrees = GAUCHE (staggered but not anti). Eclipsed = 0, 60, 120 degrees where groups overlap. Gauche is medium energy.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Gauche is staggered (groups between each other), not the highest energy gauche form.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: The lowest-energy staggered form is ANTI (180 degrees), not 120 degrees.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Highest-energy eclipsed is 0 degrees (methyl groups directly overlapping), not 120 degrees.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Isomers: Explain why 'middle-energy eclipsed form.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Within one principal energy level, which subshell has the least energy?
questions.explanation: The energies of the subshells within a principal quantum number are as follows: s < p < d < f
questions.short_reason: Subshell energy order: s < p < d < f (alphabetical!). s is closest to nucleus, least energy needed.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: p subshell has higher energy than s within the same principal level.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: d subshell has even higher energy than p.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: f subshell has the highest energy of all subshells within a principal level.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 's' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following compounds possesses at least one σ bond?

options.D: All of the above contain at least one σ bond.

questions.explanation: All single bonds are σ bonds; double and triple bonds each contain one σ bond and one or two π bonds, respectively. The compounds CH4, C2H2, and C2H4 all contain at least one single bond and therefore contain at least one σ bond.
questions.short_reason: EVERY bond starts with a sigma! Single = 1 sigma. Double = 1 sigma + 1 pi. Triple = 1 sigma + 2 pi. Sigma is the backbone.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: CH4 has 4 C-H single bonds, each is a sigma bond - this is not the only correct answer.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: C2H2 (acetylene) has a triple bond (1 sigma + 2 pi) plus C-H bonds (sigma each).
wrong_answer_explanations.C: C2H4 (ethene) has a double bond (1 sigma + 1 pi) plus C-H bonds (all sigma).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'All of the above contain at least one σ bond.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A carbon atom participates in one double bond. As such, this carbon contains orbitals with:

options.A: hybridization between the s-orbital and one p-orbital.
options.B: hybridization between the s-orbital and two p-orbitals.
options.C: hybridization between the s-orbital and three p-orbitals.

questions.explanation: In a carbon with one double bond, sp2 hybridization occurs—that is, one s-orbital hybridizes with two p-orbitals to form three sp2-hybridized orbitals. The third p-orbital of the carbon atom remains unhybridized and takes part in the formation of the π bond of the double bond. Although there is an unhybridized p-orbital, there are no unhybridized s-orbitals, eliminating (D).
questions.short_reason: Count the attachments! Double bond = 3 attachments = sp2. Triple bond = 2 attachments = sp. Single bonds only = 4 attachments = sp3.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: sp hybridization is for 2 regions of electron density (triple bonds or linear molecules).
wrong_answer_explanations.C: sp3 is for 4 regions of electron density - double bonds leave only 3 regions.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: The s-orbital IS hybridized in sp2 - one s combines with two p orbitals.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'hybridization between the s-orbital and two p-orbitals.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The hybridizations of the carbon and nitrogen atoms in CN− are:
questions.explanation: The carbon and nitrogen atoms are connected by a triple bond in CN– (:C≡N:–). A triple-bonded atom is sp hybridized; one s-orbital hybridizes with one p-orbital to form two sp-hybridized orbitals. The two remaining unhybridized p-orbitals take part in the formation of two π bonds.
questions.short_reason: Triple bond = sp + sp! Both atoms in a triple bond use sp hybridization (2 regions of electron density each).

wrong_answer_explanations.A: sp3 is for 4 regions of electron density - triple bonds leave only 2.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Both atoms in a triple bond are sp, not different hybridizations.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Same error as B - triple bonds make both atoms sp hybridized.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'sp and sp, respectively.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following hybridizations does the Be atom in BeH2 assume?
questions.explanation: Beryllium has only two electrons in its valence shell. When it bonds to two hydrogens, it requires two hybridized orbitals, meaning that its hybridization must be sp. Note that the presence of only single bonds does not mean that the hybridization must be sp3; this is a useful assumption for carbon, but does not apply to beryllium because of its smaller number of valence electrons. The two unhybridized p-orbitals around beryllium are empty in BeH2, which takes on the linear geometry characteristic of sp-hybridized orbitals.
questions.short_reason: Beryllium is special! Only 2 valence electrons, forms 2 bonds = 2 regions = sp hybridization (linear geometry).

wrong_answer_explanations.B: sp2 would give 3 bonding regions - Be only forms 2 bonds.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: sp3 would give 4 bonding regions - way more than Be needs.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: sp3d requires d orbitals and 5 bonding regions - not applicable to BeH2.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'sp' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Two atomic orbitals may combine to form:
I. a bonding molecular orbital.
II. an antibonding molecular orbital.
III. hybridized orbitals.
questions.explanation: When atomic orbitals combine, they form molecular orbitals. When two atomic orbitals with the same sign are added head-to-head or tail-to-tail, they form bonding molecular orbitals. When two atomic orbitals with opposite signs are added head-to-head or tail-to-tail, they form antibonding molecular orbitals. Atomic orbitals can also hybridize, forming sp3, sp2, or sp orbitals.
questions.short_reason: Atomic orbitals combine to make ALL the options! Bonding MO (same phase), antibonding MO (opposite phase), and hybridized orbitals (mixing s with p/d).

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Bonding MOs form, but so do antibonding MOs and hybrid orbitals.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Hybridized orbitals form, but MO formation also occurs.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Both bonding AND antibonding MOs form when atomic orbitals combine.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'I, II, and III' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Molecular orbitals can contain a maximum of:

options.D: 2n2 electrons, where n is the principal quantum number of the combining atomic orbitals.

questions.explanation: Like atomic orbitals, molecular orbitals each can contain a maximum of two electrons with opposite spins. The 2n2 rule in (D) refers to the total number of electrons that can exist in a given energy shell, not in a molecular orbital.
questions.short_reason: Pauli exclusion: 2 electrons max per orbital! Applies to atomic AND molecular orbitals - opposite spins required.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: One electron is the minimum, not the maximum.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Four electrons would violate Pauli exclusion principle.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 2n^2 is for total electrons in a shell, not per molecular orbital.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'two electrons.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: π bonds are formed by which of the following orbitals?
questions.explanation: π bonds are formed by the parallel overlap of unhybridized p-orbitals. The electron density is concentrated above and below the bonding axis. A σ bond, on the other hand, can be formed by the head-to-head overlap of two s-orbitals or hybridized orbitals. In a σ bond, the density of the electrons is concentrated between the two nuclei of the bonding atoms.
questions.short_reason: Pi bonds = PARALLEL p orbitals overlapping SIDEWAYS! Sigma bonds come from head-on overlap of any orbitals.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: s orbitals can only form sigma bonds (head-on overlap).
wrong_answer_explanations.C: s + p overlap creates sigma bonds, not pi bonds.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: sp2 hybrid orbitals form sigma bonds through head-on overlap.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'Two p-orbitals' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: How many σ bonds and π bonds are present in the following compound?

options.A: Six σ bonds and one π bond
options.B: Six σ bonds and two π bonds
options.C: Five σ bonds and one π bond
options.D: Five σ bonds and two π bonds

questions.explanation: Each single bond has one σ bond, and each double bond has one σ and one π bond. In this question, there are five single bonds (five σ bonds) and one double bond (one σ bond and one π bond), which gives a total of six σ bonds and one π bond. Thus, the correct answer is (A).
questions.short_reason: Count systematically: Each single bond = 1 sigma. Each double bond = 1 sigma + 1 pi. Add them all up!

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Recount - one double bond means only one pi bond, not two.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Five single bonds gives five sigma, plus one from the double bond = six sigma.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Check your single bond count - there should be more sigma bonds.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'Six σ bonds and one π bond' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The four C–H bonds of CH4 point toward the vertices of a tetrahedron. This indicates that the hybridization of the carbon atom in methane is:
questions.explanation: The four bonds point to the vertices of a tetrahedron, which means that the angle between two bonds is 109.5°, a characteristic of sp3 orbitals. Hence, the carbon atom of CH4 is sp3-hybridized.
questions.short_reason: Tetrahedral = sp3! Four equivalent bonds pointing to corners of a tetrahedron = 109.5 degree angles = sp3 hybridization.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: sp gives linear geometry (180 degrees), not tetrahedral.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: sp2 gives trigonal planar geometry (120 degrees), not tetrahedral.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: sp3d gives trigonal bipyramidal geometry, not tetrahedral.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'sp3.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Why is a single bond stronger than a π bond?
I. π bonds have greater orbital overlap.
II. s-orbitals have more overlap than p-orbitals.
III. sp3 hybridization is always unstable.
questions.explanation: Bond strength is determined by the degree of orbital overlap; the greater the overlap, the greater the bond strength. A π bond is weaker than a single bond because there is significantly less overlap between the unhybridized p-orbitals of a π bond (due to their parallel orientation) than between the s-orbitals or hybrid orbitals of a σ bond. sp3-hybridized orbitals can be quite stable, as evidenced by the number of carbon atoms with this hybridization forming stable compounds.
questions.short_reason: More OVERLAP = stronger bond! Sigma bonds have head-on (more) overlap. Pi bonds have parallel (less) overlap. s orbitals overlap better than p.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: This is backwards - pi bonds have LESS orbital overlap than sigma bonds.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: sp3 hybridization can be very stable (like in methane). Statement III is wrong.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Both II and III would need to be true, but III is false - sp3 can be stable.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'II only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The p character of the bonds formed by the carbon atom in HCN is:
questions.explanation: The carbon bond in hydrogen cyanide (H–C≡N:) is triple-bonded, and because triple bonds require two unhybridized p-orbitals, the carbon must be sp-hybridized; sp-hybridized orbitals have 50% s character and 50% p character.
questions.short_reason: sp hybrid = 50% s + 50% p! One s orbital + one p orbital = two sp orbitals. The name tells you the ratio!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 25% p would be sp3 hybridization (one s + three p = 25% s character).
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 67% p would be sp2 hybridization (one s + two p = 33% s, 67% p).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 75% p would be sp3 hybridization (one s + three p = 75% p character).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why '50%.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
A resonance structure describes:
I. the hybrid of all possible structures that contribute to electron distribution.
II. a potential arrangement of electrons in a molecule.
III. the single form that the molecule most often takes.
questions.explanation: A resonance structure describes an arrangement of electrons in a molecule. Different resonance structures can be derived by moving electrons in unhybridized p-orbitals throughout a molecule containing conjugated bonds. In molecules that contain multiple resonance structures, some are usually more stable than others; however, each resonance structure is not necessarily the most common form a molecule takes, eliminating statement III. Statement I has reversed the terminology for resonance structures: the electron density in a molecule is the weighted average of all possible resonance structures, not the other way around.
questions.short_reason: Resonance structures show POSSIBLE electron arrangements, not the actual structure. The REAL molecule is a weighted AVERAGE of all resonance forms.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: The hybrid is the average of structures, not the other way around - terminology is reversed.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Both I and II seem correct but I has reversed terminology.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Statement III is wrong - molecules don't 'flip' between resonance forms; they exist as the hybrid.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'II only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: An electron is known to be in the n = 4 shell and the l = 2 subshell. How many possible combinations of quantum numbers could this electron have?
questions.explanation: An electron in the n = 4 shell and the l = 2 subshell can have five different values for ml: –2, –1, 0, 1, or 2. In each of these orbitals, electrons can have positive or negative spin. Thus, there are 5 × 2 = 10 possible combinations of quantum numbers for this electron.
questions.short_reason: l=2 means d subshell with 5 orbitals (ml = -2,-1,0,1,2). Each orbital holds 2 electrons (spin up/down). Total = 5 x 2 = 10!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 1 combination ignores the multiple ml values and spin options.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 2 combinations would only account for spin options of a single orbital.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 5 combinations accounts for ml values but ignores the two spin states.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why '10' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Compared to single bonds, triple bonds are:

options.C: made up of fewer σ bonds.

questions.explanation: π bonds do not permit free rotation, unlike σ bonds; this makes triple bonds more rigid than single bonds. Triple bonds are stronger and shorter bonds than single bonds, eliminating (A) and (B). Both single and triple bonds contain one σ bond, eliminating (C).
questions.short_reason: Triple bonds: STRONGER (3 bonds worth), SHORTER (pulled closer), MORE RIGID (no rotation around pi bonds). Still has one sigma bond!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Triple bonds are STRONGER than single bonds, not weaker (more bonds = more strength).
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Triple bonds are SHORTER than single bonds (more bonds pull atoms closer).
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Both single and triple bonds have exactly ONE sigma bond - triple just adds two pi bonds.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Bonding: Explain why 'more rigid.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following are Lewis bases?
I. Ag+
II. H2O
III. NH3
questions.explanation: NH3 and H2O are Lewis bases because nitrogen and oxygen can donate lone pairs. Ag+ is a Lewis acid because it can accept a lone pair into an unoccupied orbital.
questions.short_reason: Lewis bases DONATE electron pairs (have lone pairs to give). NH3 and H2O have lone pairs. Ag+ ACCEPTS electrons (Lewis acid)!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Ag+ is a Lewis ACID - it accepts electron pairs, it doesn't donate them.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Ag+ is not a Lewis base - it's missing electrons and wants to accept them.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Ag+ is definitely not a Lewis base - it's the classic example of a Lewis acid.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'II and III only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Rank the following in order of decreasing nucleophilicity in an aprotic solvent: RO–, RCOOH, ROH, HO–
questions.explanation: Remember, good nucleophiles tend to have lone pairs or π bonds and are negatively charged or polarized. Alkoxide (OR–) and hydroxide (OH–) anions are strong nucleophiles. Alcohols (ROH) and carboxylic acids (RCOOH) are weak nucleophiles. The alkyl group of an alkoxide anion donates additional electron density, making it more reactive than the hydroxide ion. The carboxylic acid contains more electron-withdrawing oxygen atoms than the alcohol, making it less nucleophilic.
questions.short_reason: Better nucleophile = more electron-rich + less hindered. Negatives beat neutrals. Alkyl groups donate electrons (make RO- better than HO-).

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Neutral species (RCOOH, ROH) are weaker nucleophiles than anions.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Order is mixed up - charged species (anions) are better nucleophiles than neutrals.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: RCOOH is the worst nucleophile here - electron-withdrawing oxygens reduce nucleophilicity.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'RO– > HO– > ROH > RCOOH' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Rank the following in order of decreasing electrophilicity:
questions.explanation: Good electrophiles are positively charged or polarized. CR3+ is a tertiary carbocation; it has a positive charge, which makes it very electrophilic. CH3Cl and CH3OH are both polarized; however, the leaving groups differ between these two. Cl– is a weaker base than OH– (HCl is a stronger acid than H2O). As such, Cl– will be more stable in solution than OH–, which increases the electrophilic reactivity of CH3Cl above CH3OH. CH3OCH3 has a much less stable leaving group, CH3O–, and is therefore significantly less electrophilic.
questions.short_reason: Good electrophile = wants electrons! Positive charge or partial positive (delta+). Better leaving group = more electrophilic.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Check the leaving groups - carbocations are best, then consider which neutral species has better leaving group.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Consider leaving group stability - which species will most readily accept electrons?
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Rearrange based on both charge and leaving group ability.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'I (CR₃⁺) > II (carbonyl C) > III (enone) > IV (alkene)' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Rank the following in order of decreasing leaving group ability: H2O, HO–, Br–, H–
questions.explanation: Good leaving groups are weak bases, which are the conjugates of strong acids. Leaving groups must also be stable once they leave the molecule. H2O is, by far, the most stable leaving group and will be extremely unreactive once it leaves the molecule through heterolysis. Br– is the conjugate base of HBr; HO– is the conjugate base of water. HBr is a much stronger acid than water, so Br– is a better leaving group than HO–. Finally, hydride (H–) is a very poor leaving group because it is extremely unstable in solution.
questions.short_reason: Good leaving group = WEAK base = stable after leaving! H2O is neutral and stable. Br- is stable (weak base). HO- and H- are strong bases = bad leaving groups!

wrong_answer_explanations.B: HO- is a stronger base than Br- (water is weaker acid than HBr), so HO- is worse leaving group.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: H2O is neutral and stable - it's actually the BEST leaving group here.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: This order is inverted - weak bases are good leaving groups, strong bases are poor ones.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'H2O > Br– > HO– > H–' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Rank the following in order of decreasing oxidation state: amine, carboxylic acid, aldehyde, alkane
questions.explanation: Carboxylic acids are the second most oxidized form of carbon (only carbon dioxide is more oxidized). In carboxylic acids, the carbon atom has three bonds to oxygen. In aldehydes, the carbon atom has two bonds to oxygen. In amines, the carbon atom has one bond to nitrogen. In an alkane, the carbon only has bonds to other carbons and hydrogens.
questions.short_reason: More bonds to oxygen = more oxidized! CO2 (most) > COOH (3 bonds to O) > CHO (2 bonds) > amine (1 to N) > alkane (0).

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Aldehyde is not the most oxidized - carboxylic acid has more bonds to oxygen.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Amine has only one bond to nitrogen, less oxidized than both aldehyde and carboxylic acid.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: This is completely reversed - alkanes are the LEAST oxidized.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'Carboxylic acid, aldehyde, amine, alkane' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The last step in the Grignard reaction is acidification, in which the alkoxide ion is protonated to form the final alcohol product. During this reaction, the alkoxide ion acts as a:
questions.explanation: During this reaction, the alkoxide anion accepts a proton, meaning this molecule acts as a Brønsted-Lowry base. Also, in accepting the proton, the alkoxide anion donates a lone pair of electrons to form a coordinate covalent bond with the incoming hydrogen ion. In this way, the alkoxide anion is also acting as a Lewis base. Together, these observations support (B).
questions.short_reason: Accepts proton = Bronsted-Lowry base. Donates electron pair = Lewis base. Alkoxide does BOTH simultaneously!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: The alkoxide also acts as a Bronsted-Lowry base by accepting a proton.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: The alkoxide is definitely not a Lewis acid - it's donating electrons, not accepting them.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Not just Bronsted-Lowry - donating the lone pair to H+ makes it a Lewis base too.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'Brønsted–Lowry base and Lewis base' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: If 2-butanol was treated with dichromate, what reaction would occur?

options.A: Reduction, resulting in the formation of butene
options.B: Oxidation, resulting in the formation of butanoic acid
options.C: Oxidation, resulting in the formation of butanone

questions.explanation: Because 2-butanol is a secondary alcohol, oxidation by a strong oxidizing agent like dichromate will result in a ketone, butanone.
questions.short_reason: Secondary alcohols + strong oxidizer (dichromate) = KETONE! Can't go further because there's no H on the carbonyl carbon to remove.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Reduction would mean adding hydrogen - dichromate is an oxidizing agent.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 2-butanol is a secondary alcohol - you get ketone, not carboxylic acid (that's for primary alcohols).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Dichromate definitely reacts with secondary alcohols - oxidation occurs.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'Oxidation, resulting in the formation of butanone' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: If 1-hexanol was treated with pyridinium chlorochromate, what would the end product be?
questions.explanation: Pyridinium chlorochromate is a weak oxidizing agent, and will oxidize an alcohol to an aldehyde. Stronger oxidizing agents are required to convert a primary alcohol to a carboxylic acid.
questions.short_reason: PCC = Polite Chromium Complex - it STOPS at aldehyde! Too gentle to oxidize aldehydes to carboxylic acids. Perfect for primary alcohol to aldehyde.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 2-Hexanol would be the product if it were reduced, but this is oxidation.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 2-Hexanone is a ketone - would form from secondary alcohol, not primary.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: PCC is too weak to push oxidation all the way to carboxylic acid.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'Hexanal' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: SN1 reactions show first-order kinetics because:

options.A: the rate-limiting step is the first step to occur in the reaction.
options.B: the rate-limiting step involves only one molecule.
options.C: there is only one rate-limiting step.
options.D: the reaction involves only one molecule.

questions.explanation: An SN1 reaction is a first-order nucleophilic substitution reaction. It is called first-order because the rate-limiting step involves only one molecule. (A) is true, but does not explain why SN1 reactions have first-order kinetics; the rate-limiting step of an SN2 reaction is also the first (and only) step of that reaction, but SN2 reactions have second-order kinetics, not first-order. (C) is a true statement as well, but again does not explain why the reaction is first-order. Finally, (D) is incorrect because it is the rate-limiting step, not the reaction overall, that involves only one molecule.
questions.short_reason: SN1 = Substitution Nucleophilic UNIMOLECULAR. Rate-limiting step has just ONE molecule (the substrate leaving). Only [substrate] in rate law!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Being 'first' to occur doesn't explain the kinetics - it's about how many molecules are in that step.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Having one rate-limiting step is true of most reactions - not unique to first-order kinetics.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: The whole reaction involves multiple molecules - it's the rate-limiting STEP that's unimolecular.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'the rate-limiting step involves only one molecule.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: In a protic solvent, which of the following halogens would be the best nucleophile?
questions.explanation: In a protic solvent, the protons in solution can attach to the nucleophile, decreasing its nucleophilicity. The larger the nucleophile, and the stronger its conjugate acid, the stronger the nucleophile will be. Of the options given, I– will therefore be the strongest nucleophile because it is least likely to associate with the protons in solution.
questions.short_reason: Protic solvents H-bond to small nucleophiles! Large I- can't be surrounded/stabilized as easily, so it stays reactive. Big and in charge!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Br- is smaller than I- and will be more stabilized (less reactive) by protic solvent.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Cl- is even smaller - more H-bonding, more stabilization, less nucleophilic.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: F- is tiny and forms very strong H-bonds - heavily stabilized, weakest nucleophile in protic solvent.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'I–' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the compounds below can undergo oxidation by PCC?
questions.explanation: Primary and secondary alcohols can be oxidized by PCC because the central carbon atom can form additional bonds with oxygen while losing bonds to hydrogen, justifying (D) as the right answer. Choices (A), a tertiary alcohol; (B), a ketone; and (C), a carboxylic acid, cannot be oxidized by PCC because the central carbon in these molecules is already making four bonds to other carbon or oxygen atoms, and therefore cannot readily form more bonds to oxygen.
questions.short_reason: PCC oxidizes alcohols with H on the carbon. Primary and secondary alcohols have this H. Tertiary alcohols, ketones, and carboxylic acids don't!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Tertiary alcohol has no H on the carbon bearing -OH - nothing to remove during oxidation.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Ketone is already oxidized - the carbonyl carbon has no H for PCC to remove.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Carboxylic acid is fully oxidized - can't be oxidized further by PCC.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'A primary or secondary alcohol' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following substrates would most rapidly undergo an SN2 reaction when paired with an appropriate nucleophile?
questions.explanation: To carry out a nucleophile–electrophile reaction, the nucleophile must be able to dissolve in the solvent. Nucleophiles are nearly always polar, and often carry a charge. Polar solvents are therefore preferred for these reactions. Hexane is a nonpolar solvent and will not be useful for a nucleophile–electrophile reaction.
questions.short_reason: SN2 loves METHYL and PRIMARY carbons - less steric hindrance for backside attack! Secondary is slow, tertiary is impossible.

wrong_answer_explanations.B: More substituted carbons block the nucleophile's approach - slower SN2.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Tertiary carbons cannot undergo SN2 - too much steric hindrance.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Compare the structures - less substitution around the leaving group = faster SN2.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'Methyl bromide (CH₃Br)' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following solvents would be LEAST useful for a nucleophile–electrophile reaction?
questions.explanation: To carry out a nucleophile–electrophile reaction, the nucleophile must be able to dissolve in the solvent. Nucleophiles are nearly always polar, and often carry a charge. Polar solvents are therefore preferred for these reactions. Hexane is a nonpolar solvent and will not be useful for a nucleophile–electrophile reaction.
questions.short_reason: Nucleophiles are POLAR and often CHARGED - they need polar solvents to dissolve! Hexane is nonpolar = nucleophile won't dissolve.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Water is polar and dissolves charged nucleophiles well.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Ethanol is polar protic - good for dissolving nucleophiles.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: DMSO is polar aprotic - excellent for nucleophilic reactions.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'CH3CH2CH2CH2CH2CH3' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Aldehydes are generally more reactive than equivalent ketones to nucleophiles. This is likely due to differences in:
questions.explanation: Aldehydes have one alkyl group connected to the carbonyl carbon, whereas ketones have two. This creates more steric hindrance in ketones, which lowers their reactivity to nucleophiles. Ketones are also less reactive because their carbonyl carbon has less positive charge character; the additional alkyl group can donate electron density—the opposite of (D)—which decreases the electrophilicity of the compound.
questions.short_reason: Aldehydes: 1 R group + 1 H on carbonyl = less crowded. Ketones: 2 R groups = more crowded. Less steric hindrance = easier nucleophilic attack!

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Neither aldehydes nor ketones have leaving groups for acyl substitution - this is addition chemistry.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Resonance stabilization is similar in aldehydes and ketones - not the key difference.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: The extra alkyl group in ketones DONATES electrons, making the carbonyl LESS electrophilic.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'steric hindrance.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which conversion between carboxylic acid derivatives is NOT possible by a nucleophilic reaction?
questions.explanation: Remember, there is a hierarchy to the reactivity of carboxylic acid derivatives that dictates how reactive they are toward nucleophilic attack. In order from highest to lowest, this is anhydrides > carboxylic acids and esters > amides. In practical terms, this means that derivatives of higher reactivity can form derivatives of lower reactivity but not vice versa. Nucleophilic attack of an ester cannot result in the corresponding anhydride because anhydrides are more reactive than esters.
questions.short_reason: Reactivity hierarchy: anhydride > acid = ester > amide. Can only go DOWN the ladder (more reactive to less reactive), never up!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Carboxylic acid to ester is possible - they're at similar reactivity levels, slight activation makes it work.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Ester to carboxylic acid (hydrolysis) is very common - works with water.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Anhydride to amide works - anhydride is more reactive, can form less reactive amide.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Analyzing Organic Reactions: Explain why 'Ester to anhydride' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Alcohols have higher boiling points than their analogous hydrocarbons because:

options.A: the oxygen atoms in alcohols have shorter bond lengths.
options.B: hydrogen bonding is present in alcohols.
options.C: alcohols are more acidic than their analogous hydrocarbons.
options.D: alcohols can be oxidized to ketones.

questions.explanation: Alcohols have higher boiling points than their analogous hydrocarbons as a result of their polarized O–H bonds, in which oxygen is partially negative and hydrogen is partially positive. This enables the oxygen atoms of other alcohol molecules to be attracted to the hydrogen, forming a hydrogen bond. Heat is required to overcome these hydrogen bonds, thereby increasing the boiling point. The analogous hydrocarbons do not form hydrogen bonds and, therefore, vaporize at lower temperatures. (A) is irrelevant; oxygen’s bond length is not a factor in determining a substance’s boiling point. (C) and (D) are true statements, but are also irrelevant to boiling point determination.
questions.short_reason: O-H can HYDROGEN BOND! Hydrocarbons only have weak van der Waals forces. H-bonding requires extra energy to break = higher boiling point.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Bond lengths don't directly determine boiling points - intermolecular forces do.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Acidity affects reactivity, not boiling point directly.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Oxidation potential has nothing to do with boiling points.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Alcohols: Explain why 'hydrogen bonding is present in alcohols.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Tertiary alcohols are oxidized with difficulty because:

options.A: there is no hydrogen attached to the carbon with the hydroxyl group.
options.B: there is no hydrogen attached to the α-carbon of the carbonyl.
options.C: tertiary alcohols contain hydroxyl groups with no polarization.

questions.explanation: Tertiary alcohols can be oxidized only under extreme conditions because their substrate carbons do not have spare hydrogens to give up. Alcohol oxidation involves the removal of such a hydrogen so that carbon can instead make another bond to oxygen. If no hydrogen is present, a carbon–carbon bond must be cleaved, which requires a great deal of energy and will, therefore, occur only under extreme conditions. (B) is incorrect because alcohols are not carbonyl-containing compounds and would more properly describe a carbonyl-containing compound that is unable to form an enolate. (C) is incorrect because the hydroxyl group of the tertiary carbon is still polarized. (D) is a false statement; tertiary alcohols are still involved in other reactions, such as SN1 reactions.
questions.short_reason: Tertiary alcohol = NO hydrogen on the C-OH carbon! Oxidation requires removing that H. No H to lose = no oxidation (without breaking C-C bonds).

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Alpha-carbon of carbonyl is different - this is about the alcohol carbon itself.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: The O-H bond is still polarized - that's not the issue.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Tertiary alcohols still react (SN1, dehydration) - they're just resistant to oxidation.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Alcohols: Explain why 'there is no hydrogen attached to the carbon with the hydroxyl group.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of this molecule is:
questions.explanation: Remember, diols are named after the parent alkane, with the position of the alcohols indicated, and ending in the suffix –diol. Here the carbon chain is three carbons, with a hydroxyl group on carbons 1 and 2. Thus, the name is propane-1,2-diol.
questions.short_reason: Diols = alkane name + positions + 'diol'. 3 carbons = propane, OH on carbons 1 and 2 = propane-1,2-diol!

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Ethane-1,2-diol has only 2 carbons - count the chain length.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Dimethanol would be two separate methanol molecules, not a diol.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Dipropanol implies two propanol units, not a single diol.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Alcohols: Explain why 'propane-1,2-diol.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of this molecule is:
questions.explanation: This molecule is a phenol, not a hexanol, because the cyclic group has aromatic double bonds rather than single bonds. The methyl group is separated from the hydroxyl carbon by one carbon in between, making this molecule m-methylphenol.
questions.short_reason: Phenol = benzene ring (aromatic!) + OH. Not cyclohexanol (no double bonds). Use o/m/p for ring positions: m = 1 carbon between substituents.

wrong_answer_explanations.A: This would be if it were a cyclohexane ring (no double bonds) - it's aromatic.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: p-methylphenol would have the methyl group directly across from OH (1,4 position).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Cyclohexanol means saturated ring - this is aromatic (phenol).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Alcohols: Explain why 'm-methylphenol.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists methanol, isobutyl alcohol, and propanol by decreasing boiling point?
questions.explanation: All else being equal, boiling points increase with increasing size of the alkyl chain because of increased van der Waals attractions. Isobutyl alcohol has the largest alkyl chain and will thus have the highest boiling point; methanol has the smallest chain and will thus have the lowest boiling point.
questions.short_reason: Longer carbon chain = more surface area = stronger van der Waals forces = higher boiling point! Isobutyl (4C) > propanol (3C) > methanol (1C).

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Methanol has the shortest chain - lowest boiling point, not highest.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Isobutyl alcohol should be highest (longest chain), not in the middle.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Isobutyl has more carbons than propanol - it should boil higher.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Organic Chemistry - Alcohols: Explain why 'Isobutyl alcohol > propanol > methanol' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists hexanol, phenol, and cyclohexanol by increasing acidity of the hydroxyl hydrogen?
questions.explanation: Phenols have significantly more acidic hydroxyl hydrogens than other alcohols because of resonance stabilization of the conjugate base, so this will be the most acidic hydroxyl hydrogen. The acidity of hexanol and cyclohexanol are close, but the hydroxyl hydrogen of hexanol is slightly more acidic because the ring structure of cyclohexanol is slightly electron-donating, which makes its hydroxyl hydrogen slightly less acidic.
questions.short_reason: Phenol is special! The benzene ring stabilizes the conjugate base through resonance. This makes phenol WAY more acidic than regular alcohols.
